summary: This is a defense expert disclosure filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team in her criminal case. It details the proposed testimony of two defense experts, Dr. Elizabeth Loftus on memory science and Dr. Park Dietz on forensic psychiatry, aiming to challenge the reliability of witness memories and the prosecution's 'grooming' theory. This document is a defense filing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, providing notice of expert witnesses and summarizing their expected testimony. It includes a detailed discussion of psychological factors that could lead to false allegations of sexual assault, and lists several defense experts in psychiatry, law, computer forensics, financial investigation, and document examination.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)), whose counsel is submitting this expert disclosure to challenge the prosecution's evidence and theories.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon Morgan and Foreman, P.C. who is submitting this expert disclosure on behalf of defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: Distinguished Professor of Psychological Science and Law at UC Irvine, proposed as a defense expert to testify on the science of memory, false memories, and the effects of suggestion.

persons.name: Park Dietz
persons.context: Forensic psychiatrist proposed as a defense expert to critique the prosecution's grooming theory, discuss hindsight bias, the halo effect, and pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: Presumably a prosecution expert whose opinions on 'grooming' and victim vulnerabilities are being critiqued and challenged by defense expert Dr. Park Dietz in this disclosure.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as having pleaded guilty to sexual contact with minors. Dr. Dietz's testimony discusses his personality traits, manipulation tactics, and use of the 'halo effect' to attract powerful associates.

persons.name: Steve Bannon
persons.context: Mentioned as having conducted a videotaped interview with Jeffrey Epstein where Epstein discussed different kinds of power.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Cited by Dr. Dietz as an example of a person with 'political power' that Jeffrey Epstein was said to gravitate towards, illustrating the 'halo effect'.

persons.name: Gerry Edelman
persons.context: Cited by Dr. Dietz as an example of a person with 'intellectual power' that Jeffrey Epstein was said to gravitate towards, illustrating the 'halo effect'.

persons.name: Natalie Bennett
persons.context: Co-author of a cited academic paper ('The Construct of Grooming in Child Sexual Abuse') referenced by Dr. Dietz to argue grooming lacks a consistent definition.

persons.name: William O'Donohue
persons.context: Co-author of two academic papers cited by Dr. Dietz: one on the construct of grooming and another on pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Jessica Engle
persons.context: Co-author with William O'Donohue of a cited paper on pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Ryan Hall
persons.context: Defense expert in forensic psychiatry who will offer opinions and diagnoses contained in his report (Exhibit E).

persons.name: Bennett Gershman
persons.context: Distinguished Professor of Law at Pace University expected to testify on prosecutorial misconduct and best practices to ensure the integrity of a prosecution.

persons.name: Robert Kelso
persons.context: CEO of Forensic Pursuit expected to testify about user data, documents, photographs, and metadata from devices seized in the case.

persons.name: Gerald LaPorte
persons.role: Forensic Chemist and Document Dating Specialist
persons.context: Expert expected to analyze documents for dates of creation, completeness, alteration, and manipulation.

persons.name: Jennifer Naso
persons.context: Expert expected to examine documents for authorship and authentication.

persons.name: Emily R. Dworkin
persons.context: Author of meta-analysis on risk for mental disorders associated with sexual assault, cited in the defense's discussion.

persons.name: Caron Zlotnick
persons.context: Co-author of research on chronicity in PTSD, cited in the defense's discussion.

persons.name: Meredith Warshaw
persons.context: Co-author of research on chronicity in PTSD, cited in the defense's discussion.

connections.description: Maxwell is accused of recruiting and grooming minors to provide sexualized massages for Epstein, characterized in the document as an alleged 'grooming-by-proxy' relationship.
Pagliuca is submitting this expert disclosure as counsel for defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Dr. Loftus is a defense expert retained to testify on memory science in support of Maxwell's defense.
Dr. Dietz is a defense expert retained to provide forensic psychiatric testimony critiquing the prosecution's theories in support of Maxwell's defense.
Epstein gave a videotaped interview to Bannon, where he discussed concepts of power.
Epstein is described as gravitating towards people with power like Clinton's political power.
Epstein is described as gravitating towards people with power like Edelman's intellectual power.
Dr. Dietz is providing expert opinions intended to critique and counter the proposed testimony of prosecution expert Dr. Rocchio.
Dr. Hall is a defense expert witness retained to offer forensic psychiatry opinions in Maxwell's case.
Professor Gershman is a defense expert witness expected to testify on prosecutorial misconduct in Maxwell's case.
Kelso is a defense expert witness expected to testify on computer forensics related to devices in Maxwell's case.

events.title: Defense Expert Disclosure Filing
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files a summary of proposed expert testimony from Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Park Dietz pursuant to Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea Referenced
events.description: The document references that Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to having sexual contact with post-pubescent minors, which is cited as an example of outcome knowledge that can create hindsight bias.

events.title: Defense Expert Witness Disclosure
events.description: Defense files notice listing multiple expert witnesses they intend to call at trial, covering psychiatry, law, computer forensics, financial investigation, and document examination.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Haddon Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East 10th Avenue, Denver, Colorado 80203
University of California, Irvine School of Law
University of Virginia School of Law
keyFacts: The defense plans to call memory expert Dr. Elizabeth Loftus to testify about the creation of false memories, the effects of suggestion, and how media coverage can contaminate memory.

The defense plans to call forensic psychiatrist Dr. Park Dietz to challenge the prosecution's theory of 'grooming,' arguing it imputes motive without evidence and that a theory of 'grooming-by-proxy' has no scientific support.

Dr. Dietz's testimony will address cognitive biases like 'hindsight bias' (overestimating predictability after knowing an outcome) and the 'halo effect' (where positive traits influence overall perception), suggesting these affected how people viewed Epstein and Maxwell.
Dr. Dietz cites an academic article proposing 11 psychological pathways to false allegations of sexual assault, including lying, false memories, personality disorders, and intoxication.
The document reveals a core defense strategy: attacking the reliability of witness memories and the scientific validity of the prosecution's 'grooming' narrative.

The defense is preparing to argue that false allegations of sexual assault can arise from various psychological factors, including false memory, intoxication, and personality disorders (Antisocial, Borderline, Histrionic).
Multiple defense expert witnesses are disclosed, including a forensic psychiatrist (Ryan Hall), a prosecutorial misconduct scholar (Bennett Gershman), and a computer forensics expert (Robert Kelso).
The defense cites academic research, including work by Elizabeth Loftus on false memories, to support its arguments about witness reliability.
The filing indicates the defense plans to challenge the credibility of accusers by suggesting their allegations could be influenced by mental health conditions or memory distortions.
The defense reserves the right to rebut the testimony of a prosecution expert named Dr. Rocchio and any accuser claims of being 'groomed'.
